Subjecting an appointee to any other detriment
The person who has the power in relation to the matter to which the conduct in question relates (or, if there is no such person, the person who has the power to make the appointment).
The person who has the power in relation to the matter to which the conduct in question relates.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A reference to terminating a person's appointment includes a reference to termination of the appointment—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by the expiry of a period (including a period expiring by reference to an event or circumstance);
by an act of the person (including giving notice) in circumstances such that the person is entitled, because of the relevant person's conduct, to terminate the appointment without notice.
Subsection (7)(a) does not apply if, immediately after the termination, the appointment is renewed on the same terms.
Schedule 6 (excluded offices) has effect.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not discriminate against a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding upon whom to confer a relevant qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a relevant qualification on B;
by not conferring a relevant qualification on B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not discriminate against a person (B) upon whom A has conferred a relevant qualification—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by withdrawing the qualification from B;
by varying the terms on which B holds the qualification;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body must not, in relation to conferment by it of a relevant qualification, harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a person who holds the qualification, or
a person who applies for it.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not victimise a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding upon whom to confer a relevant qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a relevant qualification on B;
by not conferring a relevant qualification on B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not victimise a person (B) upon whom A has conferred a relevant qualification—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by withdrawing the qualification from B;
by varying the terms on which B holds the qualification;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to a qualifications body.
The application by a qualifications body of a competence standard to a disabled person is not disability discrimination unless it is discrimination by virtue of section 19.
This section applies for the purposes of section 53.
A qualifications body is an authority or body which can confer a relevant qualification.

A relevant qualification is an authorisation, qualification, recognition, registration, enrolment, approval or certification which is needed for, or facilitates engagement in, a particular trade or profession.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An authority or body is not a qualifications body in so far as—

ns0:content.ns0:p: it can confer a qualification to which section 96 applies,
it is the responsible body of a school to which section 85 applies,
it is the governing body of an institution to which section 91 applies,
it exercises functions under the Education Acts, or
it exercises functions under the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.
A reference to conferring a relevant qualification includes a reference to renewing or extending the conferment of a relevant qualification.
A competence standard is an academic, medical or other standard applied for the purpose of determining whether or not a person has a particular level of competence or ability.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A person (an “employment service-provider”) concerned with the provision of an employment service must not discriminate against a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements the service-provider makes for selecting persons to whom to provide, or to whom to offer to provide, the service;
as to the terms on which the service-provider offers to provide the service to the person;
by not offering to provide the service to the person.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An employment service-provider (A) must not, in relation to the provision of an employment service, discriminate against a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: as to the terms on which A provides the service to B;
by not providing the service to B;
by terminating the provision of the service to B;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An employment service-provider must not, in relation to the provision of an employment service, harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a person who asks the service-provider to provide the service;
a person for whom the service-provider provides the service.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An employment service-provider (A) must not victimise a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for selecting persons to whom to provide, or to whom to offer to provide, the service;
as to the terms on which A offers to provide the service to B;
by not offering to provide the service to B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An employment service-provider (A) must not, in relation to the provision of an employment service, victimise a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: as to the terms on which A provides the service to B;
by not providing the service to B;
by terminating the provision of the service to B;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to an employment service-provider, except in relation to the provision of a vocational service.

The duty imposed by section 29(7)(a) applies to a person concerned with the provision of a vocational service; but a failure to comply with that duty in relation to the provision of a vocational service is a contravention of this Part for the purposes of Part 9 (enforcement).
This section applies for the purposes of section 55.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The provision of an employment service includes—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the provision of vocational training;
the provision of vocational guidance;
making arrangements for the provision of vocational training or vocational guidance;
the provision of a service for finding employment for persons;
the provision of a service for supplying employers with persons to do work;
the provision of a service in pursuance of arrangements made under section 2 of the Employment and Training Act 1973 (functions of the Secretary of State relating to employment);
the provision of a service in pursuance of arrangements made or a direction given under section 10 of that Act (careers services);
the exercise of a function in pursuance of arrangements made under section 2(3) of the Enterprise and New Towns (Scotland) Act 1990 (functions of Scottish Enterprise, etc. relating to employment);

an assessment related to the conferment of a relevant qualification within the meaning of section 53 above (except in so far as the assessment is by the qualifications body which confers the qualification).
This section does not apply in relation to training or guidance in so far as it is training or guidance in relation to which another provision of this Part applies.

This section does not apply in relation to training or guidance for pupils of a school to which section 85 applies in so far as it is training or guidance to which the responsible body of the school has power to afford access (whether as the responsible body of that school or as the responsible body of any other school at which the training or guidance is provided).

This section does not apply in relation to training or guidance for students of an institution to which section 91 applies in so far as it is training or guidance to which the governing body of the institution has power to afford access.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Vocational training” means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: training for employment, or
work experience (including work experience the duration of which is not agreed until after it begins).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A reference to the provision of a vocational service is a reference to the provision of an employment service within subsection (2)(a) to (d) (or an employment service within subsection (2)(f) or (g) in so far as it is also an employment service within subsection (2)(a) to (d)); and for that purpose—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the references to an employment service within subsection (2)(a) do not include a reference to vocational training within the meaning given by subsection (6)(b), and
the references to an employment service within subsection (2)(d) also include a reference to a service for assisting persons to retain employment.
A reference to training includes a reference to facilities for training.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation (A) must not discriminate against a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding to whom to offer membership of the organisation;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to admit B as a member;
by not accepting B's application for membership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation (A) must not discriminate against a member (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it affords B access, or by not affording B access, to opportunities for receiving a benefit, facility or service;
by depriving B of membership;
by varying the terms on which B is a member;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation must not, in relation to membership of it, harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a member, or
an applicant for membership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation (A) must not victimise a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding to whom to offer membership of the organisation;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to admit B as a member;
by not accepting B's application for membership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation (A) must not victimise a member (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it affords B access, or by not affording B access, to opportunities for receiving a benefit, facility or service;
by depriving B of membership;
by varying the terms on which B is a member;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to a trade organisation.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A trade organisation is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: an organisation of workers,
an organisation of employers, or
any other organisation whose members carry on a particular trade or profession for the purposes of which the organisation exists.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A local authority must not discriminate against a member of the authority in relation to the member's carrying out of official business—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way the authority affords the member access, or by not affording the member access, to opportunities for training or for receiving any other facility;
by subjecting the member to any other detriment.
A local authority must not, in relation to a member's carrying out of official business, harass the member.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A local authority must not victimise a member of the authority in relation to the member's carrying out of official business—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way the authority affords the member access, or by not affording the member access, to opportunities for training or for receiving any other facility;
by subjecting the member to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A member of a local authority is not subjected to a detriment for the purposes of subsection (1)(b) or (3)(b) only because the member is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: not appointed or elected to an office of the authority,
not appointed or elected to, or to an office of, a committee or sub-committee of the authority, or
not appointed or nominated in exercise of an appointment power of the authority.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In subsection (4)(c), an appointment power of a local authority is a power of the authority, or of a group of bodies including the authority, to make—

ns0:content.ns0:p: appointments to a body;
nominations for appointment to a body.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to a local authority.
This section applies for the purposes of section 58.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Local authority” means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a county council in England;
a district council in England;
the Greater London Authority;
a London borough council;
the Common Council of the City of London;
the Council of the Isles of Scilly;
a parish council in England;
a county council in Wales;
a community council in Wales;
a county borough council in Wales;

ns0:p.ns0:ins: a corporate joint committee established by regulations made under Part 5 of the Local Government and Elections (Wales) Act 2021;

ns0:content.ns0:p: a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc. (Scotland) Act 1994;
a community council in Scotland.

A Minister of the Crown may by order amend subsection (2) so as to add, vary or omit a reference to a body which exercises functions that have been conferred on a local authority within paragraph (a) to (l).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A reference to the carrying-out of official business by a person who is a member of a local authority is a reference to the doing of anything by the person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: as a member of the authority,
as a member of a body to which the person is appointed by, or appointed following nomination by, the authority or a group of bodies including the authority, or
as a member of any other public body.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Member”, in relation to the Greater London Authority, means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the Mayor of London;
a member of the London Assembly.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A person (A) to whom an application for work is made must not ask about the health of the applicant (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: before offering work to B, or
where A is not in a position to offer work to B, before including B in a pool of applicants from whom A intends (when in a position to do so) to select a person to whom to offer work.

A contravention of subsection (1) (or a contravention of section 111 or 112 that relates to a contravention of subsection (1)) is enforceable as an unlawful act under Part 1 of the Equality Act 2006 (and, by virtue of section 120(8), is enforceable only by the Commission under that Part).

A does not contravene a relevant disability provision merely by asking about B's health; but A's conduct in reliance on information given in response may be a contravention of a relevant disability provision.

Subsection (5) applies if B brings proceedings before an employment tribunal on a complaint that A's conduct in reliance on information given in response to a question about B's health is a contravention of a relevant disability provision.

In the application of section 136 to the proceedings, the particulars of the complaint are to be treated for the purposes of subsection (2) of that section as facts from which the tribunal could decide that A contravened the provision.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section does not apply to a question that A asks in so far as asking the question is necessary for the purpose of—

ns0:content.ns0:p: establishing whether B will be able to comply with a requirement to undergo an assessment or establishing whether a duty to make reasonable adjustments is or will be imposed on A in relation to B in connection with a requirement to undergo an assessment,
establishing whether B will be able to carry out a function that is intrinsic to the work concerned,
monitoring diversity in the range of persons applying to A for work,

taking action to which section 158 would apply if references in that section to persons who share (or do not share) a protected characteristic were references to disabled persons (or persons who are not disabled) and the reference to the characteristic were a reference to disability, or
if A applies in relation to the work a requirement to have a particular disability, establishing whether B has that disability.

In subsection (6)(b), where A reasonably believes that a duty to make reasonable adjustments would be imposed on A in relation to B in connection with the work, the reference to a function that is intrinsic to the work is to be read as a reference to a function that would be intrinsic to the work once A complied with the duty.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Subsection (6)(e) applies only if A shows that, having regard to the nature or context of the work—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the requirement is an occupational requirement, and
the application of the requirement is a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim.

“Work” means employment, contract work, a position as a partner, a position as a member of an LLP, a pupillage or tenancy, being taken as a devil, membership of a stable, an appointment to a personal or public office, or the provision of an employment service; and the references in subsection (1) to offering a person work are, in relation to contract work, to be read as references to allowing a person to do the work.

A reference to offering work is a reference to making a conditional or unconditional offer of work (and, in relation to contract work, is a reference to allowing a person to do the work subject to fulfilment of one or more conditions).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The following, so far as relating to discrimination within section 13 because of disability, are relevant disability provisions—

ns0:content.ns0:p: section 39(1)(a) or (c);
section 41(1)(b);
section 44(1)(a) or (c);
section 45(1)(a) or (c);
section 47(1)(a) or (c);
section 48(1)(a) or (c);
section 49(3)(a) or (c);
section 50(3)(a) or (c);
section 51(1);
section 55(1)(a) or (c);

ns0:p.ns0:ins: section 60A(1).

ns0:content.ns0:p: An assessment is an interview or other process designed to give an indication of a person's suitability for the work concerned.
For the purposes of this section, whether or not a person has a disability is to be regarded as an aspect of that person's health.
This section does not apply to anything done for the purpose of vetting applicants for work for reasons of national security.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: A person (A) must not make a discriminatory statement in connection with a relevant decision that A makes or might make.
References in this section to a “relevant decision” are to be determined as follows—
Where A is—
A relevant decision is—
An employer
Deciding to whom to offer employment
A principal (as defined by section 41(5))
Deciding whether to allow a contract worker (as defined by section 41(7)) to do, or to continue to do, work
A firm or proposed firm (as defined by section 46(2) and (3))
Deciding to whom to offer a position as a partner (read in accordance with section 44(8))
An LLP or proposed LLP (as defined by section 46(4) and (5))
Deciding to whom to offer a position as a member
A barrister or a barrister’s clerk (read in accordance with section 47(8))
Deciding to whom to offer a pupillage or tenancy
An advocate (as defined by section 48(9)) or an advocate’s clerk (read in accordance with section 48(8))
Deciding who to take as a devil or to whom to offer membership of a stable
A person with power to make an appointment to a personal office (as defined by section 49(2))
Deciding to whom to offer the appointment
A person with power to make an appointment to a public office within section 50(2)(a), (b) or (d)
Deciding to whom to offer the appointment
A person with power to make a recommendation for or give approval to an appointment to a public office within section 50(2)(a), (b) or (d) (read in accordance with section 51(5))
Deciding who to recommend for appointment or to whose appointment to give approval
A qualifications body (as defined by section 54)
Deciding to whom to confer a relevant qualification (as defined by section 54)
A person concerned with the provision of an employment service (read in accordance with section 56)
Deciding on the selection of persons to whom to provide, or to whom to offer to provide, the employment service
A trade organisation (as defined by section 57(7))
Deciding to whom to offer membership of the organisation.
For the purposes of subsection (1) a statement is discriminatory if—
it is directed to the public or a section of the public, and
were it made in connection with a relevant decision, the making of it would amount to treatment of a person that is direct discrimination.
A statement made by a person (B) who—
is not an employee of A acting in the course of B’s employment, and
is not an agent of A acting with A’s authority,

is to be treated for the purposes of this section as if made by A if there are reasonable grounds for the public, or a section of the public, to believe that B is capable of exercising decisive influence on the making by A of a relevant decision.
Regard is to be had (among other things) to the factors mentioned in subsection (6) when determining—
whether a statement is made in connection with a relevant decision for the purposes of subsection (1);
whether there are reasonable grounds for the belief mentioned in subsection (4).
The factors are—
the status of the person making the statement at the time it is made;
the nature and content of the statement;
the context in which the statement is made;
in the case of a statement that A is treated as having made by virtue of subsection (4), the steps (if any) taken by A to disassociate A from the statement made by B.
It does not matter for the purposes of this section whether or not—
an individual has or may have been affected by the discriminatory statement in question;
A has made, or plans to make, arrangements which would involve the making of a relevant decision.

A contravention of subsection (1) (or a contravention of section 111 or 112 that relates to a contravention of subsection (1)) is enforceable as an unlawful act under Part 1 of the Equality Act 2006 (and, by virtue of section 120(8), is enforceable only by the Commission under that Part).
In subsection (3) the reference to direct discrimination is to a contravention of this Act by virtue of section 13 or 18.
Nothing in this section limits or otherwise affects—
other prohibitions imposed by this Chapter;
the application of section 109 (liability of employers and principals for acts of employees and agents).

ns0:content.ns0:p: An occupational pension scheme must be taken to include a non-discrimination rule.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A non-discrimination rule is a provision by virtue of which a responsible person (A)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: must not discriminate against another person (B) in carrying out any of A's functions in relation to the scheme;
must not, in relation to the scheme, harass B;
must not, in relation to the scheme, victimise B.
The provisions of an occupational pension scheme have effect subject to the non-discrimination rule.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The following are responsible persons—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the trustees or managers of the scheme;
an employer whose employees are, or may be, members of the scheme;
a person exercising an appointing function in relation to an office the holder of which is, or may be, a member of the scheme.
A non-discrimination rule does not apply in relation to a person who is a pension credit member of a scheme.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An appointing function is any of the following—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the function of appointing a person;
the function of terminating a person's appointment;
the function of recommending a person for appointment;
the function of approving an appointment.
A breach of a non-discrimination rule is a contravention of this Part for the purposes of Part 9 (enforcement).

It is not a breach of a non-discrimination rule for the employer or the trustees or managers of a scheme to maintain or use in relation to the scheme rules, practices, actions or decisions relating to age which are of a description specified by order by a Minister of the Crown.

An order authorising the use of rules, practices, actions or decisions which are not in use before the order comes into force must not be made unless the Minister consults such persons as the Minister thinks appropriate.

A non-discrimination rule does not have effect in relation to an occupational pension scheme in so far as an equality rule has effect in relation to it (or would have effect in relation to it but for Part 2 of Schedule 7).
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to a responsible person.
This section applies if the trustees or managers of an occupational pension scheme do not have power to make non-discrimination alterations to the scheme.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section also applies if the trustees or managers of an occupational pension scheme have power to make non-discrimination alterations to the scheme but the procedure for doing so—

ns0:content.ns0:p: is liable to be unduly complex or protracted, or
involves obtaining consents which cannot be obtained or which can be obtained only with undue delay or difficulty.
The trustees or managers may by resolution make non-discrimination alterations to the scheme.
Non-discrimination alterations may have effect in relation to a period before the date on which they are made.

Non-discrimination alterations to an occupational pension scheme are such alterations to the scheme as may be required for the provisions of the scheme to have the effect that they have in consequence of section 61(3).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In their application to communications the following provisions apply in relation to a disabled person who is a pension credit member of an occupational pension scheme as they apply in relation to a disabled person who is a deferred member or pensioner member of the scheme—

ns0:content.ns0:p: section 61;
section 120;
section 126;
paragraph 19 of Schedule 8 (and such other provisions of that Schedule as apply for the purposes of that paragraph).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Communications include—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the provision of information;
the operation of a dispute resolution procedure.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Sections 66 to 70 apply where—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a person (A) is employed on work that is equal to the work that a comparator of the opposite sex (B) does;
a person (A) holding a personal or public office does work that is equal to the work that a comparator of the opposite sex (B) does.
The references in subsection (1) to the work that B does are not restricted to work done contemporaneously with the work done by A.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: Sections 66 to 68 and 70 apply where a person (A) is or has been in pensionable service under an occupational pension scheme (regardless of whether those sections also apply in A’s case by virtue of subsection (1)).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: For the purposes of this Chapter, A's work is equal to that of B if it is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: like B's work,
rated as equivalent to B's work, or
of equal value to B's work.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A's work is like B's work if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: A's work and B's work are the same or broadly similar, and
such differences as there are between their work are not of practical importance in relation to the terms of their work.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: So on a comparison of one person's work with another's for the purposes of subsection (2), it is necessary to have regard to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the frequency with which differences between their work occur in practice, and
the nature and extent of the differences.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A's work is rated as equivalent to B's work if a job evaluation study—

ns0:content.ns0:p: gives an equal value to A's job and B's job in terms of the demands made on a worker, or
would give an equal value to A's job and B's job in those terms were the evaluation not made on a sex-specific system.
A system is sex-specific if, for the purposes of one or more of the demands made on a worker, it sets values for men different from those it sets for women.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A's work is of equal value to B's work if it is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: neither like B's work nor rated as equivalent to B's work, but
nevertheless equal to B's work in terms of the demands made on A by reference to factors such as effort, skill and decision-making.
If the terms of A's work do not (by whatever means) include a sex equality clause, they are to be treated as including one.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Where this section applies by virtue of section 64(1), a sex equality clause is a provision that has the following effect—

ns0:content.ns0:p: if a term of A's is less favourable to A than a corresponding term of B's is to B, A's term is modified so as not to be less favourable;
if A does not have a term which corresponds to a term of B's that benefits B, A's terms are modified so as to include such a term.
Subsection (2)(a) applies to a term of A's relating to membership of or rights under an occupational pension scheme only in so far as a sex equality rule would have effect in relation to the term.

In the case of work within section 65(1)(b), a reference in subsection (2) above to a term includes a reference to such terms (if any) as have not been determined by the rating of the work (as well as those that have).

ns0:p.ns0:ins: Where this section applies by virtue of section 64(3), a sex equality clause is a provision that has the effect that if, by virtue of the application of the guaranteed minimum pension provisions, a term of A’s that relates to membership of or rights under the scheme concerned is less favourable to A than it would be if A were of the opposite sex, the term, in so far as a sex equality rule would have effect in relation to it, is modified so as not to be less favourable.
” means so much of the Pension Schemes Act 1993 and of any other enactment as relates to guaranteed minimum pensions (within the meaning of that Act).

ns0:content.ns0:p: If an occupational pension scheme does not include a sex equality rule, it is to be treated as including one.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Where this section applies by virtue of section 64(1), a sex equality rule is a provision that has the following effect—

ns0:content.ns0:p: if a relevant term is less favourable to A than it is to B, the term is modified so as not to be less favourable;

if a term confers a relevant discretion capable of being exercised in a way that would be less favourable to A than to B, the term is modified so as to prevent the exercise of the discretion in that way.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: Where this section applies by virtue of section 64(3), a sex equality rule is a provision that has the following effect—

if, by virtue of the application of the guaranteed minimum pension provisions, a relevant term is less favourable to A than it would be if A were of the opposite sex, the term is modified so as not to be less favourable;

if, by virtue of the application of those provisions, a term confers a relevant discretion capable of being exercised in a way that would be less favourable to A than it would be if A were of the opposite sex, the term is modified so as to prevent the exercise of the discretion in that way.
” means so much of the Pension Schemes Act 1993 and of any other enactment as relates to guaranteed minimum pensions (within the meaning of that Act).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A term is relevant if it is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a term on which persons become members of the scheme, or
a term on which members of the scheme are treated.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A discretion is relevant if its exercise in relation to the scheme is capable of affecting—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the way in which persons become members of the scheme, or
the way in which members of the scheme are treated.
The reference in subsection (3)(b) to a term on which members of a scheme are treated includes a reference to the term as it has effect for the benefit of dependants of members.

The reference in subsection (4)(b) to the way in which members of a scheme are treated includes a reference to the way in which they are treated as the scheme has effect for the benefit of dependants of members.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: If the effect of a relevant matter on a person (A) differs according to the effect it has on a person of the same sex as A, according to whether A is married, in a civil partnership, or for some other reason due to A’s family status, a comparison for the purposes of this section of the effect of that matter on persons of the opposite sex must be with a person of the opposite sex to A who is in the same position as A and in particular—
where A is married to
someone of the opposite sex, A is to be compared to a person of the opposite sex to A (“B”) where B is married to

ns0:ins.ns0:ins: or (as the case may be) the civil partner of

ns0:p.ns0:ins: someone of the opposite sex to B;

ns0:ins.ns0:ins: where A is married to, or the civil partner of, someone of the same sex, A is to be compared to B where B is married to or (as the case may be) the civil partner of someone of the same sex as B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A relevant matter is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a relevant term;
a term conferring a relevant discretion;
the exercise of a relevant discretion in relation to an occupational pension scheme.
This section, so far as relating to the terms on which persons become members of an occupational pension scheme, does not have effect in relation to pensionable service before 8 April 1976.
This section, so far as relating to the terms on which members of an occupational pension scheme are treated, does not have effect in relation to pensionable service before 17 May 1990.

ns0:section.ns0:heading: Sex equality rule: consequential alteration of schemes

ns0:content.ns0:p: This section applies if the trustees or managers of an occupational pension scheme do not have power to make sex equality alterations to the scheme.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section also applies if the trustees or managers of an occupational pension scheme have power to make sex equality alterations to the scheme but the procedure for doing so—

ns0:content.ns0:p: is liable to be unduly complex or protracted, or
involves obtaining consents which cannot be obtained or which can be obtained only with undue delay or difficulty.
The trustees or managers may by resolution make sex equality alterations to the scheme.
Sex equality alterations may have effect in relation to a period before the date on which they are made.
Sex equality alterations to an occupational pension scheme are such alterations to the scheme as may be required to secure conformity with a sex equality rule.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The sex equality clause in A's terms has no effect in relation to a difference between A's terms and B's terms if the responsible person shows that the difference is because of a material factor reliance on which—

ns0:content.ns0:p: does not involve treating A less favourably because of A's sex than the responsible person treats B, and
if the factor is within subsection (2), is a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim.

A factor is within this subsection if A shows that, as a result of the factor, A and persons of the same sex doing work equal to A's are put at a particular disadvantage when compared with persons of the opposite sex doing work equal to A's.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the long-term objective of reducing inequality between men's and women's terms of work is always to be regarded as a legitimate aim.

A sex equality rule has no effect in relation to a difference between A and B in the effect of a relevant matter if the trustees or managers of the scheme in question show that the difference is because of a material factor which is not the difference of sex.
“Relevant matter” has the meaning given in section 67.
For the purposes of this section, a factor is not material unless it is a material difference between A's case and B's.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The relevant sex discrimination provision has no effect in relation to a term of A's that—

ns0:content.ns0:p: is modified by, or included by virtue of, a sex equality clause or rule, or
would be so modified or included but for section 69 or Part 2 of Schedule 7.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Neither of the following is sex discrimination for the purposes of the relevant sex discrimination provision—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the inclusion in A's terms of a term that is less favourable as referred to in section 66(2)(a);
the failure to include in A's terms a corresponding term as referred to in section 66(2)(b).
The relevant sex discrimination provision is, in relation to work of a description given in the first column of the table, the provision referred to in the second column so far as relating to sex.

ns0:section.ns0:heading: Sex discrimination in relation to contractual pay

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section applies in relation to a term of a person's work—

ns0:content.ns0:p: that relates to pay, but
in relation to which a sex equality clause or rule has no effect.

The relevant sex discrimination provision (as defined by section 70) has no effect in relation to the term except in so far as treatment of the person amounts to a contravention of the provision by virtue of section 13 or 14.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Sections 73 to 76 apply where a woman—

ns0:content.ns0:p: is employed, or
holds a personal or public office.
If the terms of the woman's work do not (by whatever means) include a maternity equality clause, they are to be treated as including one.
A maternity equality clause is a provision that, in relation to the terms of the woman's work, has the effect referred to in section 74(1), (6) and (8).
In the case of a term relating to membership of or rights under an occupational pension scheme, a maternity equality clause has only such effect as a maternity equality rule would have.

A term of the woman's work that provides for maternity-related pay to be calculated by reference to her pay at a particular time is, if each of the following three conditions is satisfied, modified as mentioned in subsection (5).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The first condition is that, after the time referred to in subsection (1) but before the end of the protected period—

ns0:content.ns0:p: her pay increases, or
it would have increased had she not been on maternity leave.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The second condition is that the maternity-related pay is not—

ns0:content.ns0:p: what her pay would have been had she not been on maternity leave, or
the difference between the amount of statutory maternity pay to which she is entitled and what her pay would have been had she not been on maternity leave.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The third condition is that the terms of her work do not provide for the maternity-related pay to be subject to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: an increase as mentioned in subsection (2)(a), or
an increase that would have occurred as mentioned in subsection (2)(b).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The modification referred to in subsection (1) is a modification to provide for the maternity-related pay to be subject to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: any increase as mentioned in subsection (2)(a), or
any increase that would have occurred as mentioned in subsection (2)(b).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A term of her work that—

ns0:content.ns0:p: provides for pay within subsection (7), but
does not provide for her to be given the pay in circumstances in which she would have been given it had she not been on maternity leave,

ns0:wrapUp.ns0:p: is modified so as to provide for her to be given it in circumstances in which it would normally be given.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Pay is within this subsection if it is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: pay (including pay by way of bonus) in respect of times before the woman is on maternity leave,
pay by way of bonus in respect of times when she is on compulsory maternity leave, or
pay by way of bonus in respect of times after the end of the protected period.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A term of the woman's work that—

ns0:content.ns0:p: provides for pay after the end of the protected period, but
does not provide for it to be subject to an increase to which it would have been subject had she not been on maternity leave,

ns0:wrapUp.ns0:p: is modified so as to provide for it to be subject to the increase.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Maternity-related pay is pay (other than statutory maternity pay) to which a woman is entitled—

ns0:content.ns0:p: as a result of being pregnant, or
in respect of times when she is on maternity leave.
A reference to the protected period is to be construed in accordance with section 18.
If an occupational pension scheme does not include a maternity equality rule, it is to be treated as including one.
A maternity equality rule is a provision that has the effect set out in subsections (3) and (4).

If a relevant term does not treat time when the woman is on maternity leave as it treats time when she is not, the term is modified so as to treat time when she is on maternity leave as time when she is not.

If a term confers a relevant discretion capable of being exercised so that time when she is on maternity leave is treated differently from time when she is not, the term is modified so as not to allow the discretion to be exercised in that way.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A term is relevant if it is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a term relating to membership of the scheme,
a term relating to the accrual of rights under the scheme, or
a term providing for the determination of the amount of a benefit payable under the scheme.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A discretion is relevant if its exercise is capable of affecting—

ns0:content.ns0:p: membership of the scheme,
the accrual of rights under the scheme, or
the determination of the amount of a benefit payable under the scheme.

This section does not require the woman's contributions to the scheme in respect of time when she is on maternity leave to be determined otherwise than by reference to the amount she is paid in respect of that time.

This section, so far as relating to time when she is on ordinary maternity leave but is not being paid by her employer, applies only in a case where the expected week of childbirth began on or after 6 April 2003.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section, so far as relating to time when she is on additional maternity leave but is not being paid by her employer—

ns0:content.ns0:p: does not apply to the accrual of rights under the scheme in any case;
applies for other purposes only in a case where the expected week of childbirth began on or after 5 October 2008.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In this section—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a reference to being on maternity leave includes a reference to having been on maternity leave, and
a reference to being paid by the employer includes a reference to receiving statutory maternity pay from the employer.

ns0:section.ns0:heading: Exclusion of pregnancy and maternity discrimination provisions

ns0:content.ns0:p: The relevant pregnancy and maternity discrimination provision has no effect in relation to a term of the woman's work that is modified by a maternity equality clause or rule.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: The relevant pregnancy and maternity discrimination provision has no effect in relation to a term of the woman's work—
that relates to pay, but
in relation to which a maternity equality clause or rule has no effect.

ns0:content.ns0:p: The inclusion in the woman's terms of a term that requires modification by virtue of section 73(2) or (3) is not pregnancy and maternity discrimination for the purposes of the relevant pregnancy and maternity discrimination provision.

The relevant pregnancy and maternity discrimination provision is, in relation to a description of work given in the first column of the table, the provision referred to in the second column so far as relating to pregnancy and maternity.

A term of a person's work that purports to prevent or restrict the person (P) from disclosing or seeking to disclose information about the terms of P's work is unenforceable against P in so far as P makes or seeks to make a relevant pay disclosure.

A term of a person's work that purports to prevent or restrict the person (P) from seeking disclosure of information from a colleague about the terms of the colleague's work is unenforceable against P in so far as P seeks a relevant pay disclosure from the colleague; and “colleague” includes a former colleague in relation to the work in question.

A disclosure is a relevant pay disclosure if made for the purpose of enabling the person who makes it, or the person to whom it is made, to find out whether or to what extent there is, in relation to the work in question, a connection between pay and having (or not having) a particular protected characteristic.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The following are to be treated as protected acts for the purposes of the relevant victimisation provision—

ns0:content.ns0:p: seeking a disclosure that would be a relevant pay disclosure;
making or seeking to make a relevant pay disclosure;
receiving information disclosed in a relevant pay disclosure.

The relevant victimisation provision is, in relation to a description of work specified in the first column of the table, section 27 so far as it applies for the purposes of a provision mentioned in the second column.

ns0:p.ns0:i: Provision by virtue of which section 27 has effect

ns0:content.ns0:p: Regulations may require employers to publish information relating to the pay of employees for the purpose of showing whether, by reference to factors of such description as is prescribed, there are differences in the pay of male and female employees.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section does not apply to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: an employer who has fewer than 250 employees;
a person specified in Schedule 19;
a government department or part of the armed forces not specified in that Schedule.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The regulations may prescribe—

ns0:content.ns0:p: descriptions of employer;
descriptions of employee;
how to calculate the number of employees that an employer has;
descriptions of information;
the time at which information is to be published;
the form and manner in which it is to be published.
Regulations under subsection (3)(e) may not require an employer, after the first publication of information, to publish information more frequently than at intervals of 12 months.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The regulations may make provision for a failure to comply with the regulations—

ns0:content.ns0:p: to be an offence punishable on summary conviction by a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale;
to be enforced, otherwise than as an offence, by such means as are prescribed.
The reference to a failure to comply with the regulations includes a reference to a failure by a person acting on behalf of an employer.
This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.
If A is employed, B is a comparator if subsection (3), (4), (4A) or (4B) applies.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This subsection applies if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: B is employed by A's employer or by an associate of A's employer, and
A and B work at the same establishment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This subsection applies if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: B is employed by A's employer or an associate of A's employer,
B works at an establishment other than the one at which A works, and
common terms apply at the establishments (either generally or as between A and B).

ns0:p.ns0:ins: This subsection applies if a single body—
is responsible for setting or continuing the terms on which A and B are employed, and
is in a position to ensure equal treatment between A and B in respect of such terms.
This subsection applies if the terms on which A and B are employed are governed by the same collective agreement.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: If A holds a personal or public office, B is a comparator if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: B holds a personal or public office, and
the person responsible for paying A is also responsible for paying B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: If A is a relevant member of the House of Commons staff, B is a comparator if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: B is employed by the person who is A's employer under subsection (6) of section 195 of the Employment Rights Act 1996, or
if subsection (7) of that section applies in A's case, B is employed by the person who is A's employer under that subsection.
If A is a relevant member of the House of Lords staff, B is a comparator if B is also a relevant member of the House of Lords staff.
Section 42 does not apply to this Chapter; accordingly, for the purposes of this Chapter only, holding the office of constable is to be treated as holding a personal office.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: For the purposes of this section, employers are associated if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: one is a company of which the other (directly or indirectly) has control, or
both are companies of which a third person (directly or indirectly) has control.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: In subsection (4B) “
” has the same meaning as in the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (see section 178 of that Act).

ns0:content.ns0:p: This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The terms of a person's work are—

ns0:content.ns0:p: if the person is employed, the terms of the person's employment that are in the person's contract of employment, contract of apprenticeship or contract to do work personally;
if the person holds a personal or public office, the terms of the person's appointment to the office.
If work is not done at an establishment, it is to be treated as done at the establishment with which it has the closest connection.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A person (P) is the responsible person in relation to another person if—

ns0:content.ns0:p: P is the other's employer;
P is responsible for paying remuneration in respect of a personal or public office that the other holds.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A job evaluation study is a study undertaken with a view to evaluating, in terms of the demands made on a person by reference to factors such as effort, skill and decision-making, the jobs to be done—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by some or all of the workers in an undertaking or group of undertakings, or
in the case of the armed forces, by some or all of the members of the armed forces.
In the case of Crown employment, the reference in subsection (5)(a) to an undertaking is to be construed in accordance with section 191(4) of the Employment Rights Act 1996.
Schedule 7 (exceptions) has effect.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This Part applies in relation to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: work on ships,
work on hovercraft, and
seafarers,

ns0:wrapUp.ns0:p: only in such circumstances as are prescribed.

ns0:content.ns0:p: For the purposes of this section, it does not matter whether employment arises or work is carried out within or outside the United Kingdom.
“Ship” has the same meaning as in the Merchant Shipping Act 1995.
“Hovercraft” has the same meaning as in the Hovercraft Act 1968.
“Seafarer” means a person employed or engaged in any capacity on board a ship or hovercraft.
Nothing in this section affects the application of any other provision of this Act to conduct outside England and Wales or Scotland.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Her Majesty may by Order in Council provide that in the case of persons in offshore work—

ns0:content.ns0:p: specified provisions of this Part apply (with or without modification);
Northern Ireland legislation making provision for purposes corresponding to any of the purposes of this Part applies (with or without modification).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The Order may—

ns0:content.ns0:p: provide for these provisions, as applied by the Order, to apply to individuals (whether or not British citizens) and bodies corporate (whether or not incorporated under the law of a part of the United Kingdom), whether or not such application affects activities outside the United Kingdom;

make provision for conferring jurisdiction on a specified court or class of court or on employment tribunals in respect of offences, causes of action or other matters arising in connection with offshore work;

exclude from the operation of section 3 of the Territorial Waters Jurisdiction Act 1878 (consents required for prosecutions) proceedings for offences under the provisions mentioned in subsection (1) in connection with offshore work;
provide that such proceedings must not be brought without such consent as may be required by the Order.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Offshore work” is work for the purposes of—

ns0:content.ns0:p: activities in the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom,
activities such as are mentioned in subsection (2) of section 11 of the Petroleum Act 1998 in waters within subsection (8)(b) or (c) of that section, or
activities mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of section 87(1) of the Energy Act 2004 in waters to which that section applies.
Work includes employment, contract work, a position as a partner or as a member of an LLP, or an appointment to a personal or public office.
Northern Ireland legislation includes an enactment contained in, or in an instrument under, an Act that forms part of the law of Northern Ireland.
In the application to Northern Ireland of subsection (2)(b), the reference to employment tribunals is to be read as a reference to industrial tribunals.
Nothing in this section affects the application of any other provision of this Act to conduct outside England and Wales or Scotland.
This section applies for the purposes of this Part.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Employment” means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: employment under a contract of employment, a contract of apprenticeship or a contract personally to do work;
Crown employment;
employment as a relevant member of the House of Commons staff;
employment as a relevant member of the House of Lords staff.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This Part applies to service in the armed forces as it applies to employment by a private person; and for that purpose—

ns0:content.ns0:p: references to terms of employment, or to a contract of employment, are to be read as including references to terms of service;
references to associated employers are to be ignored.

A reference to an employer or an employee, or to employing or being employed, is (subject to section 212(11)) to be read with subsections (2) and (3); and a reference to an employer also includes a reference to a person who has no employees but is seeking to employ one or more other persons.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Relevant member of the House of Commons staff” has the meaning given in section 195 of the Employment Rights Act 1996; and such a member of staff is an employee of—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the person who is the employer of that member under subsection (6) of that section, or
if subsection (7) of that section applies in the case of that member, the person who is the employer of that member under that subsection.

“Relevant member of the House of Lords staff” has the meaning given in section 194 of that Act (which provides that such a member of staff is an employee of the Corporate Officer of the House of Lords).

In the case of a person in Crown employment, or in employment as a relevant member of the House of Commons staff, a reference to the person's dismissal is a reference to the termination of the person's employment.
A reference to a personal or public office, or to an appointment to a personal or public office, is to be construed in accordance with section 52.
“Crown employment” has the meaning given in section 191 of the Employment Rights Act 1996.
Schedule 8 (reasonable adjustments) has effect.
Schedule 9 (exceptions) has effect.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This Chapter does not apply to the following protected characteristics—

ns0:content.ns0:p: age;
marriage and civil partnership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of a school to which this section applies must not discriminate against a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is offered admission as a pupil;
as to the terms on which it offers to admit the person as a pupil;
by not admitting the person as a pupil.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such a school must not discriminate against a pupil—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it provides education for the pupil;
in the way it affords the pupil access to a benefit, facility or service;
by not providing education for the pupil;
by not affording the pupil access to a benefit, facility or service;
by excluding the pupil from the school;
by subjecting the pupil to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such a school must not harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a pupil;
a person who has applied for admission as a pupil.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such a school must not victimise a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is offered admission as a pupil;
as to the terms on which it offers to admit the person as a pupil;
by not admitting the person as a pupil.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such a school must not victimise a pupil—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it provides education for the pupil;
in the way it affords the pupil access to a benefit, facility or service;
by not providing education for the pupil;
by not affording the pupil access to a benefit, facility or service;
by excluding the pupil from the school;
by subjecting the pupil to any other detriment.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to the responsible body of such a school.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In relation to England and Wales, this section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a school maintained by a local authority;
an independent educational institution (other than a special school);

ns0:p.ns0:ins: an alternative provision Academy that is not an independent educational institution;

ns0:content.ns0:p: a special school (not maintained by a local authority).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In relation to Scotland, this section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a school managed by an education authority;
an independent school;
a school in respect of which the managers are for the time being receiving grants under section 73(c) or (d) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of a school to which this section applies is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: if the school is within subsection (7)(a), the local authority or governing body;
if it is within subsection (7)(b) , (ba) or (c), the proprietor;
if it is within subsection (8)(a), the education authority;
if it is within subsection (8)(b), the proprietor;
if it is within subsection (8)(c), the managers.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In the application of section 26 for the purposes of subsection (3), none of the following is a relevant protected characteristic—

ns0:content.ns0:p: gender reassignment;
religion or belief;
sexual orientation.

ns0:section.ns0:heading: Victimisation of pupils, etc. for conduct of parents, etc.

ns0:content.ns0:p: This section applies for the purposes of section 27 in its application to section 85(4) or (5).
The references to B in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) of section 27 include a reference to a parent or sibling of the child in question.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Giving false evidence or information, or making a false allegation, in good faith is not a protected act in a case where—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the evidence or information is given, or the allegation is made, by a parent or sibling of the child, and
the child has acted in bad faith.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Giving false evidence or information, or making a false allegation, in bad faith, is a protected act in a case where—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the evidence or information is given, or the allegation is made, by a parent or sibling of the child, and
the child has acted in good faith.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In this section—

ns0:content.ns0:p: “child” means a person who has not attained the age of 18;
“sibling” means a brother or sister, a half-brother or half-sister, or a stepbrother or stepsister.

ns0:heading.ns0:ins: Application of enforcement powers under education legislation

ns0:p.ns0:ins: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in the case of a school in Wales.

ns0:content.ns0:p: Sections 496 and 497 of the Education Act 1996 (powers to give directions where responsible body of school in default of obligations, etc.) and section 70 of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980 apply to the performance of a duty under section 85.

But neither of sections 496 and 497 of the Education Act 1996 applies to the performance of a duty under that section by the proprietor of an independent educational institution (other than a special school) or an alternative provision Academy that is not an independent educational institution; and section 70 of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980 does not apply to the performance of a duty under that section by the proprietor of an independent school.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: In the case of a school in Wales—
Chapter 1 of Part 2 of the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 (“
”) (intervention in conduct of maintained schools) applies to the performance of a duty under section 85, but as if—
the only relevant grounds for intervention were grounds 5 and 6 in section 2 of that Act, and
sections 3 to 9 and 12 to 16 of that Act did not apply;
Chapter 2 of Part 2 of the 2013 Act (intervention in local authorities) applies to the performance of a duty under section 85, but as if—
the only relevant grounds for intervention were grounds 1 and 2 in section 21 of that Act, and
sections 24 to 27 of that Act did not apply.

But neither of Chapters 1 and 2 of Part 2 of the 2013 Act applies to the performance of a duty under section 85 by the proprietor of an independent educational institution (other than a special school).

ns0:content.ns0:p: Schedule 10 (accessibility) has effect.
This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.
Nothing in this Chapter applies to anything done in connection with the content of the curriculum.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Pupil”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England and Wales, has the meaning given in section 3(1) of the Education Act 1996;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Proprietor”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to a school in England and Wales, has the meaning given in section 579(1) of the Education Act 1996;
in relation to a school in Scotland, has the meaning given in section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “School”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England and Wales, has the meaning given in section 4 of the Education Act 1996;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.

A reference to a school includes a reference to an independent educational institution in England; and a reference to an independent educational institution in England is to be construed in accordance with Chapter 1 of Part 4 of the Education and Skills Act 2008.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A reference to an independent educational institution is a reference to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: an independent educational institution in England, or
an independent school in Wales.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Independent school”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to Wales, has the meaning given in section 463 of the Education Act 1996;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.
“Special school” has the meaning given in section 337 of the Education Act 1996.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Local authority” means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England, an English local authority within the meaning of section 162 of the Education and Inspections Act 2006;
in relation to Wales, a Welsh local authority within the meaning of that section.
“Education authority”, in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.
Schedule 11 (exceptions) has effect.
This Chapter does not apply to the protected characteristic of marriage and civil partnership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of an institution to which this section applies must not discriminate against a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is offered admission as a student;
as to the terms on which it offers to admit the person as a student;
by not admitting the person as a student.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not discriminate against a student—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it provides education for the student;
in the way it affords the student access to a benefit, facility or service;
by not providing education for the student;
by not affording the student access to a benefit, facility or service;
by excluding the student;
by subjecting the student to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not discriminate against a disabled person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding upon whom to confer a qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a qualification on the person;
by not conferring a qualification on the person;
by withdrawing a qualification from the person or varying the terms on which the person holds it.
Subsection (3) applies only to disability discrimination.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a student;
a person who has applied for admission as a student;
a disabled person who holds or has applied for a qualification conferred by the institution.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not victimise a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is offered admission as a student;
as to the terms on which it offers to admit the person as a student;
by not admitting the person as a student.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not victimise a student—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the way it provides education for the student;
in the way it affords the student access to a benefit, facility or service;
by not providing education for the student;
by not affording the student access to a benefit, facility or service;
by excluding the student;
by subjecting the student to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body of such an institution must not victimise a disabled person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding upon whom to confer a qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a qualification on the person;
by not conferring a qualification on the person;
by withdrawing a qualification from the person or varying the terms on which the person holds it.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to the responsible body of such an institution.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In relation to England and Wales, this section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a university;
any other institution within the higher education sector;
an institution within the further education sector.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: a 16 to 19 Academy.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In relation to Scotland, this section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a university;
a designated institution;
a college of further education.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A responsible body is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the case of an institution within subsection (10)(a), (b) or (c), the governing body;

ns0:p.ns0:ins: in the case of an institution within subsection (10)(d), the proprietor (within the meaning of the Education Act 1996);

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the case of an institution within subsection (11)(a) or (b), the governing body;
in the case of a college of further education under the management of a board of management, the board of management;

in the case of any other college of further education, any board of governors of the college or any person responsible for the management of the college, whether or not formally constituted as a governing body or board of governors.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to a course to which this section applies must not discriminate against a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is enrolled on the course;
as to the terms on which it offers to enrol the person on the course;
by not accepting the person's application for enrolment.
The responsible body in relation to such a course must not discriminate against a person who is enrolled on the course in the services it provides or offers to provide.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to such a course must not harass a person who—

ns0:content.ns0:p: seeks enrolment on the course;
is enrolled on the course;
is a user of services provided by the body in relation to the course.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to such a course must not victimise a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is enrolled on the course;
as to the terms on which it offers to enrol the person on the course;
by not accepting the person's application for enrolment.
The responsible body in relation to such a course must not victimise a person who is enrolled on the course in the services it provides or offers to provide.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to the responsible body.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a course of further or higher education secured by a responsible body in England or Wales;
a course of education provided by the governing body of a maintained school under section 80 of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998;
a course of further education secured by an education authority in Scotland.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A responsible body is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a local authority in England or Wales, for the purposes of subsection (7)(a);
the governing body of a maintained school, for the purposes of subsection (7)(b);
an education authority in Scotland, for the purposes of subsection (7)(c).

ns0:intro.ns0:p: In this section—

ns0:content.ns0:p: “course”, in relation to further education, includes each component part of a course if there is no requirement imposed on persons registered for a component part of the course to register for another component part of the course;
“enrolment” includes registration for a component part of a course;
“maintained school” has the meaning given in section 20(7) of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998;
“services” means services of any description which are provided wholly or mainly for persons enrolled on a course to which this section applies.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to facilities to which this section applies must not discriminate against a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is provided with the facilities;
as to the terms on which it offers to provide the facilities to the person;
by not accepting the person's application for provision of the facilities.
The responsible body in relation to such facilities must not discriminate against a person who is provided with the facilities in the services it provides or offers to provide.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to such facilities must not harass a person who—

ns0:content.ns0:p: seeks to have the facilities provided;
is provided with the facilities;
is a user of services provided by the body in relation to the facilities.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The responsible body in relation to such facilities must not victimise a person—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements it makes for deciding who is provided with the facilities;
as to the terms on which it offers to provide the facilities to the person;
by not accepting the person's application for provision of the facilities.
The responsible body in relation to such facilities must not victimise a person who is provided with the facilities in the services it provides or offers to provide.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to the responsible body.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This section applies to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: facilities secured by a local authority in England under section 507A or 507B of the Education Act 1996;
facilities secured by a local authority in Wales under section 508 of that Act;
recreational or training facilities provided by an education authority in Scotland.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A responsible body is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a local authority in England, for the purposes of subsection (7)(a);
a local authority in Wales, for the purposes of subsection (7)(b);
an education authority in Scotland, for the purposes of subsection (7)(c).
This section does not apply to the protected characteristic of age, so far as relating to persons who have not attained the age of 18.
This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.
Nothing in this Chapter applies to anything done in connection with the content of the curriculum.
A reference to a student, in relation to an institution, is a reference to a person for whom education is provided by the institution.
A reference to a university includes a reference to a university college and a college, school or hall of a university.
A reference to an institution within the further or higher education sector is to be construed in accordance with section 91 of the Further and Higher Education Act 1992.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Further education”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England and Wales, has the meaning given in section 2 of the Education Act 1996;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 1(3) of the Further and Higher Education (Scotland) Act 1992.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Higher education”—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England and Wales, means education provided by means of a course of a description mentioned in Schedule 6 to the Education Reform Act 1988;
in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given in section 38 of the Further and Higher Education (Scotland) Act 1992.
“College of further education” has the meaning given in section 36 of the Further and Higher Education (Scotland) Act 1992.
“Designated institution” has the meaning given in section 44 of that Act.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: “Local authority” means—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to England, an English local authority within the meaning of section 162 of the Education and Inspections Act 2006;
in relation to Wales, a Welsh local authority within the meaning of that section.
“Education authority” has the meaning given by section 135(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.

ns0:p.ns0:ins: A reference to conferring a qualification includes a reference—
to renewing or extending the conferment of a qualification;
to authenticating a qualification conferred by another person.

ns0:content.ns0:p: Schedule 12 (exceptions) has effect.
This Chapter does not apply to the protected characteristic of marriage and civil partnership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not discriminate against a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding upon whom to confer a relevant qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a relevant qualification on B;
by not conferring a relevant qualification on B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not discriminate against a person (B) upon whom A has conferred a relevant qualification—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by withdrawing the qualification from B;
by varying the terms on which B holds the qualification;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body must not, in relation to conferment by it of a relevant qualification, harass—

ns0:content.ns0:p: a person who holds the qualification, or
a person who applies for it.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not victimise a person (B)—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in the arrangements A makes for deciding upon whom to confer a relevant qualification;
as to the terms on which it is prepared to confer a relevant qualification on B;
by not conferring a relevant qualification on B.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A qualifications body (A) must not victimise a person (B) upon whom A has conferred a relevant qualification—

ns0:content.ns0:p: by withdrawing the qualification from B;
by varying the terms on which B holds the qualification;
by subjecting B to any other detriment.
A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies to a qualifications body.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: Subsection (6) does not apply to the body in so far as the appropriate regulator specifies provisions, criteria or practices in relation to which the body—

ns0:content.ns0:p: is not subject to a duty to make reasonable adjustments;
is subject to a duty to make reasonable adjustments, but in relation to which such adjustments as the regulator specifies should not be made.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: For the purposes of subsection (7) the appropriate regulator must have regard to—

ns0:content.ns0:p: the need to minimise the extent to which disabled persons are disadvantaged in attaining the qualification because of their disabilities;
the need to secure that the qualification gives a reliable indication of the knowledge, skills and understanding of a person upon whom it is conferred;
the need to maintain public confidence in the qualification.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The appropriate regulator—

ns0:content.ns0:p: must not specify any matter for the purposes of subsection (7) unless it has consulted such persons as it thinks appropriate;
must publish matters so specified (including the date from which they are to have effect) in such manner as is prescribed.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: The appropriate regulator is—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to a qualifications body that confers qualifications in England, a person prescribed by a Minister of the Crown;
in relation to a qualifications body that confers qualifications in Wales, a person prescribed by the Welsh Ministers;
in relation to a qualifications body that confers qualifications in Scotland, a person prescribed by the Scottish Ministers.

For the purposes of subsection (10), a qualification is conferred in a part of Great Britain if there are, or may reasonably be expected to be, persons seeking to obtain the qualification who are or will be assessed for those purposes wholly or mainly in that part.
This section applies for the purposes of section 96.
A qualifications body is an authority or body which can confer a relevant qualification.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A relevant qualification is an authorisation, qualification, approval or certification of such description as may be prescribed—

ns0:content.ns0:p: in relation to conferments in England, by a Minister of the Crown;
in relation to conferments in Wales, by the Welsh Ministers;
in relation to conferments in Scotland, by the Scottish Ministers.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An authority or body is not a qualifications body in so far as—

ns0:content.ns0:p: it is the responsible body of a school to which section 85 applies,
it is the governing body of an institution to which section 91 applies,
it exercises functions under the Education Acts, or
it exercises functions under the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.
A qualifications body does not include an authority or body of such description, or in such circumstances, as may be prescribed.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: A reference to conferring a relevant qualification includes a reference—

ns0:content.ns0:p: to renewing or extending the conferment of a relevant qualification;
to authenticating a relevant qualification conferred by another person.
A reference in section 96(8), (10) or (11) to a qualification is a reference to a relevant qualification.
Subsection (11) of section 96 applies for the purposes of subsection (3) of this section as it applies for the purposes of subsection (10) of that section.
Schedule 13 (reasonable adjustments) has effect.
Schedule 14 (educational charities and endowments) has effect.
This Part does not apply to the protected characteristic of marriage and civil partnership.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: This Part does not apply to discrimination, harassment or victimisation—

ns0:content.ns0:p: that is prohibited by Part 3 (services and public functions), Part 4 (premises), Part 5 (work) or Part 6 (education), or
that would be so prohibited but for an express exception.

ns0:intro.ns0:p: An association (A) must not discriminate against a person (B)—
